metadata.title: Straddle Options Calculator (Long & Short)
metadata.description: Interactive calculator to analyze long and short straddle option positions. Computes initial cost/credit, profit or loss at expiration, breakeven points, and provides clear assumptions, accuracy caveats and references to standards for numerical and software quality.

long_straddle.label: Long Straddle (Buy Call + Buy Put)
long_straddle.description: Buy one call and one put at the same strike. Calculates initial cost, profit/loss at expiration, and breakeven prices.

short_straddle.label: Short Straddle (Sell Call + Sell Put)
short_straddle.description: Sell one call and one put at the same strike. Calculates initial credit, profit/loss at expiration, and breakeven prices. Highlights unlimited risk characteristics.

fields.label: Notes (informational)
fields.default: Use the position type selector to switch between long and short straddle calculations.

introduction: This Straddle Options Calculator analyzes long and short straddle positions (call and put at the same strike) and returns initial cost or credit, profit or loss at expiration, and breakeven prices. It is intended for scenario analysis and educational use, not as trading advice.
The tool separates position types (long vs short), shows explicit commissions, and reports breakeven points so you can understand both limited and unlimited risk profiles.
methodology: Calculations use elementary option payoff mathematics at expiration: payoff is the sum of call and put intrinsic values minus the net premium paid or plus the net premium received. For long positions the tool reports net cash outflow (cost). For short positions it reports net cash inflow (credit) and highlights downside/upside risk.

Numerical implementation and software quality follow established guidance: numerical formats adhere to IEEE 754 floating-point conventions; development and validation practices align with ISO 9001 quality management principles; cryptographic and secure handling recommendations reference NIST cybersecurity guidance; and user safety and warnings reference general workplace safety guidance principles. See citations for authoritative sources.
how_is_calculated: Total premium (per share) = Call premium + Put premium
Initial cost (long) = (Total premium * contracts * 100) + Total commissions
Initial credit (short) = (Total premium * contracts * 100) - Total commissions
Intrinsic call = max(S - K, 0); Intrinsic put = max(K - S, 0)
Profit/Loss at expiration (long) = (Intrinsic call + Intrinsic put) * contracts * 100 - Initial cost
Profit/Loss at expiration (short) = Initial credit - (Intrinsic call + Intrinsic put) * contracts * 100
Breakeven prices = K ± Total premium (per share)
examples: Example 1 — Long straddle: underlying price 100, strike 100, call premium 3.50, put premium 3.50, one contract. Total premium 7.00. Initial cost about 700 plus commissions. Breakeven levels 93.00 and 107.00. Profit occurs if the price ends below 93 or above 107 at expiration.

Example 2 — Short straddle: same inputs but sold. Initial credit about 700 minus commissions. Loss is potentially unlimited if the underlying rises above the upper breakeven or large if it falls below the lower breakeven.

faqs.question: Does this calculator price options using Black-Scholes or implied volatility?
faqs.answer: No. This tool computes payoff at expiration from premiums you enter. It does not compute theoretical option prices from volatility. For model-derived Greeks or theoretical pricing, use a dedicated pricing calculator that models implied volatility and time value.

faqs.question: Are transaction costs and margin included?
faqs.answer: Commission per leg is included in initial cost/credit. Margin requirements and pattern day-trading or broker margin rules are not modeled; consult your broker for margin specifics.

faqs.question: How accurate are numeric results?
faqs.answer: Results are arithmetic calculations based on your inputs. Numerical rounding follows IEEE floating-point rules; display rounding is to two decimal places for currency. Validate significant decisions with your own risk checks and, if required, institution-grade pricing tools.

faqs.question: Is this a recommendation to trade?
faqs.answer: No. This calculator is educational and analytical. It does not account for liquidity, slippage, execution risk, or tax consequences. Consult a licensed financial professional for personalized advice.

glossary.definition: An options strategy that combines a call and a put with the same strike and expiration. A long straddle is a buy of both; a short straddle is a sell of both.
The price per share paid (or received) for an option. One standard contract controls 100 shares.
For calls: max(S - K, 0). For puts: max(K - S, 0). It is the option value if exercised immediately.
The underlying prices at expiration where the position neither makes nor loses money, equal to K ± total premium (per share).
Total cash paid (cost for long) or received (credit for short) when opening the straddle, including commissions.
